title: Jane Fonda Talks Environmental Activism at Bloomberg Green Seattle | Bloomberg Talks

would I be brave enough? Could I have

And so
I'm sure you have people, young people,

And if we we do them, we won't be

What I do and the fact that I'm not

Right.
Probably true.
So to that end, what ignited you?
What made you think about this back in the day?
I think the fact that I was born in 1937 and spent the first 10 years of my life in California was important.
There were only two billion people on earth then.
Is this working?
Yeah.
Uh, two billion people and guess what?
Two billion people is the caring capacity of earth when it comes to us guys.

You know, what are we going to eat?
Well, we'll eat cell grown fish, I guess.
But, um, no, really, we're destroying our So, you all know that as better than I do.
Um but what that meant for me was you know most people in the 30s they lived in in the country they didn't live in cities and that meant there was a lot of nature you I lived on on the top of a mountain overlooking kind of like this overlooking the Pacific Ocean only not so close farther away and there was no smog there were no freeways there was no plastic and we did just fine we did it was maybe more difficult, but it was just fine.
Um, but you know, I grew I woke up and went to sleep to the sound of coyotes.
I heard morning doves and and and night and gales and meadow larkarks and bobcats and mountain lions and I grew up with animals and I was always outside like a lot of you probably, you know, it was the solace for me.
It was not so great inside the house.
Yeah, there's something wrong.
Oh well.
Um, anyway, I came back.
I moved away.
I came back 40 years later, lived near the beach, and people were getting cancer.
Lifeguards were getting cancer.
This ocean that I swam in every summer, I didn't want to go in.
People's eyes were burning.
My kids got asthma.
It's like this was not the same.
And then I was married to a man named Tom Hayden who was a a movement leader at the time.
And and he we focused a lot on prochemicals.
There was the hole in the ozone.
There was there was the cancer.
There was Dowo Chemical was was one of the main villains at the time.
Um, anyway, I so I've always cared about the environment.
I've always cared about the creatures, the wildlife.
And then we discovered through the work against prochemicals that corporations were running the government.
Yeah.
Actually, my husband interviewed Jimmy Carter when he was in the White House and and Carter said to him, "One of the things that I've realized now is the corporations are running this country."
That was the president that said that.
So, um, so I've always cared.
I've always, you know, loved nature and the environment and didn't like what corporations were doing to it.
And then, but I didn't really follow the science.
I didn't really know until like 2018 the degree to which the climate was being challenged primarily by the burning of fossil fuels and that wasn't being talked about then.
all the most of the big green organizations with the exception of Greenpeace and Oil Change International and a few others, they talked about the the alternatives, the you know the the things that we were working for, but they never said what was the primary cause of the climate crisis.
And you can't solve the climate crisis unless you talk about what's causing it primarily.
And it wasn't until I started reading um Naomi Klein's couple of books that she wrote um that made me realize this is this is existential.
This is different than anything that we have ever faced before.
And um and I got very very depressed.
I know what that feels like because I knew I wasn't doing enough.
And I called Annie Leonard who was running Greenpeace at the time.
She's here.
She's the bravest, smartest, most strategic person I know.
And I said, "I want to move to DC and create a ruckus.
I want to camp in front of the White House and and I'm going to really, you know, cook up some good trouble.
I was worried about where to poop."
I've done this before and I'm going to do it again.
Yeah.
Pooping was a problem.
I didn't know how do you do what do you I you know I know what to do in a blizzard or in the country or in a forest but well how what do you do with your poop when you're camping and and protesting in a city.
Think about that gentlemen.
But but she said you don't have to worry about pooping because it's not allowed anymore.
You're not allowed to camp out.
And so long story short camping not pooping.
Okay.
Okay.
Um we created fire drill Fridays which meant every Friday we we you know we would focus on a particular topic involving the climate crisis and then we would engage in non-violent civil disobedience.
I mean th this is what changes history.
You people if you look at the history of nonviolent civil disobedience it's what's really changed things a lot.
Um and so we did that and it changed us a lot.
Um, our goal was not to pressure the government.
Trump was in office.
We wanted to We knew that about 65 to 70% of Americans were concerned about climate.
We wanted to move from concern to action.
And I was I turned 82 in jail that that fall.
And I knew that was very important because a lot of people said people said, "Well, if she can do it," you know, people people came from all over the country, mostly gay-haired women like me, and they came, they'd never been at rallies before.
They'd never uh been arrested before.
And and it really mattered.
It made a big difference.
We we there were a lot of new activists came out of that.
And when COVID hit, we took it online and for a year we had nine million people that would join us on across all platforms.
When when COVID ended and Annie and a very small team, the board that we have, it's a small group of people.
